config.question: Why did thousands of Japanese Americans renounce their American citizenship and resettle in Japan after World War II?

choices.content: The U.S. Congress had decreed that every Japanese American be treated as an enemy and deported.
They felt disillusioned after losing their possessions and being detained in internment camps during the war.
The economic downturn in the United States after the end of World War II made it difficult for many Japanese Americans to find employment.
The rebuilding Japanese government offered financial incentives to all Japanese Americans who immigrated to Asia.

answer_3.response: Consider This: President Roosevelt approved an army order in February 1942 that affected Japanese Americans, two-thirds of which were Nisei. The Nisei were native-born Americans. The all-Nisei 442nd Combat Team served gallantly in Europe, losing more than 500 men in battle and winning more than 1000 citations for bravery. See L.O. 27.4 The Home Front.
